skill.name: agentic-structure
skill.description: Collaborative programming framework for production-ready development. Use when starting features, writing code, handling security/errors, adding comments, discussing requirements, or encountering knowledge gaps. Applies to all development tasks for clear, safe, maintainable code.
skill.summary: Collaborative programming framework for production-ready development. Use when starting features, wr...
skill.author: BackGwa

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation files. No executable code, network operations, filesystem access, or command execution. The skill provides development guidelines for AI coding assistants.

content.value_statement: Developers struggle with inconsistent code quality and security gaps when working with AI assistants. This skill provides comprehensive guidelines for collaborative development including coding standards, error handling, security practices, and decision-making protocols.
actual_capabilities: Guides implementation order from core logic to interface
Provides security-first coding guidelines and secrets handling
Defines error handling patterns and recovery strategies
Establishes discussion protocols for ambiguous requirements
Documents commenting and knowledge sharing workflows
Enforces coding standards and file organization rules
limitations: Does not execute code or modify files directly
Does not integrate with external APIs or services
Does not provide runtime validation or testing
Requires user to apply guidelines manually in their workflow

use_cases.title: Establish team coding standards
use_cases.description: Set consistent coding conventions, error handling patterns, and security practices across all AI-assisted development work.

use_cases.title: Enforce security-first development
use_cases.description: Apply security guidelines for secrets management, authentication, rate limiting, and input validation in all code generated.

use_cases.title: Guide collaborative decision-making
use_cases.description: Define when AI assistants should ask for clarification versus proceeding autonomously based on architectural impact.

prompt_templates.title: Start New Feature
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to implement [feature description]. Apply the Development Process guidelines to help me plan this feature. Start by identifying the core logic, integration points, and interface components I need to build.

prompt_templates.title: Handle Ambiguity
prompt_templates.prompt: My request is unclear: [original request]. Use the Discussion Guidelines to identify the ambiguous terms and ask me clarifying questions to determine the single correct interpretation.

prompt_templates.title: Write Secure Code
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to [task description]. Apply the Security Guidelines to ensure this implementation uses proper secrets handling, authentication, authorization, and abuse prevention. Report any security concerns before proceeding.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor Complex Code
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code section: [code or description]. Apply the Coding Standards to identify nesting issues, abstraction opportunities, and refactoring triggers. Explain what changes would improve maintainability.

output_examples.input: Create a user authentication endpoint for my API
output: Before implementing, I need to clarify: What authentication method (JWT, session, OAuth)? What rate limits apply? Should I use existing patterns in the codebase?
Recommended implementation order: 1) Core authentication logic, 2) Integration with user store, 3) Error handling and security checks, 4) API response formatting
Security considerations: Store secrets in environment variables, use bcrypt for password hashing, apply rate limiting per IP, validate all inputs server-side

best_practices: Apply security guidelines first when handling sensitive data or user input - security always takes precedence over other considerations.
Use the guideline matrix to select the right reference for each task rather than reading all documentation upfront.
When requirements are ambiguous, pause and ask clarifying questions rather than proceeding with assumptions.
anti_patterns: Proceeding with implementation when multiple valid approaches exist without user alignment on trade-offs.
Adding comments that merely restate what the code does rather than explaining why the code exists.
Using try-catch blocks broadly without specific recovery strategies or meaningful error context.

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Apply guidelines when writing code, handling errors, or making architectural decisions.

faq.question: How many guidelines should I read at once?
faq.answer: Use the Guideline Selection Matrix in SKILL.md to find the relevant document for your current task. Read only what you need.

faq.question: Do I need to follow all guidelines simultaneously?
faq.answer: No. When guidelines conflict, follow the priority order: Security first, then Development Process, then Error Handling, Coding Standards, and Comments last.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-only skill with no code execution, network access, or file operations. It only provides development guidance.

faq.question: What if I disagree with a guideline?
faq.answer: Apply judgment based on context. The guidelines state that progress over perfection is acceptable - moving in the right direction matters more than perfect adherence.

faq.question: How does this compare to writing code directly?
faq.answer: This skill does not write code for you. It provides prompts and frameworks that help AI assistants produce higher-quality, more secure, and more maintainable code.
